title: Celebrating Wins
description: Explore how you acknowledge and celebrate each other's achievements.

questions.text: When something good happens to me, I want you to...
choices: Celebrate enthusiastically with me
Listen and share in my happiness
Ask questions and show genuine interest
Acknowledge it warmly but simply

therapeutic.rationale: How we want our wins celebrated reflects our love language and validation needs. Enthusiastic celebrators want energy; listeners want presence; questioners want engagement; acknowledgers want recognition. Gottman's research shows how partners respond to good news is crucial for relationship health.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different celebration needs require learning your partner's preferred response. The enthusiast may overwhelm the simple-acknowledger; adjust to what your partner actually wants.
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched celebration preferences mean you'll naturally give each other what you need when good things happen.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you want your partner to respond when good things happen to you? Have you told them?

questions.text: When you achieve something, I naturally...
choices: Feel genuinely happy for you
Want to celebrate and mark the moment
Think about how I can support more of this
Feel proud to be your partner

therapeutic.rationale: Responses to partner success reflect attachment and relationship orientation. Genuine happiness shows secure attachment; celebration shows expressiveness; future-support shows investment; pride shows positive identification with partner. All are healthy responses.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different responses to partner success are all valid expressions of care. What matters is that positive response is present.
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched responses to partner success create reciprocal joy when good things happen.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you feel when your partner succeeds? Does your partner know that's how you feel?

questions.text: For me, what makes a celebration meaningful is...
choices: That you're genuinely present and happy
Making it a special occasion
Your words of acknowledgment
Sharing the moment together, however simple

therapeutic.rationale: What makes celebration meaningful reveals core emotional needs. Presence-seekers value attention; occasion-makers value ritual; word-seekers value verbal affirmation; sharers value togetherness. Knowing this helps partners celebrate in ways that truly land.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different celebration values require learning what resonates for your partner. The elaborate celebration may miss the mark if your partner just wants your presence.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared celebration values mean your instinctive way of celebrating will match what your partner actually wants.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What makes a celebration feel meaningful to you? Is that what you usually receive?

questions.text: I wish we celebrated more often when...
choices: Small wins happen, not just big ones
We overcome something difficult together
One of us grows or improves
We reach milestones as a couple

therapeutic.rationale: Celebration gaps reveal what's being under-acknowledged. Small wins need daily recognition; overcoming difficulty deserves honor; growth needs encouragement; milestones need marking. Expanding what you celebrate strengthens the relationship.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different celebration gaps point to different kinds of acknowledgment you each need more of. This is valuable data for improving how you appreciate each other.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared celebration gaps create clear direction for expanding how you acknowledge each other.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What would you like to celebrate more often in your relationship? What's stopping you?

choices: Build a positive culture in our relationship
Feel more connected and appreciative
Stay motivated to keep growing
Remember that we're on each other's team

therapeutic.rationale: Understanding celebration's value reinforces the behavior. Positive culture prevents negativity cycles; connection deepens bonds; motivation sustains effort; team-feeling reinforces partnership. Research shows couples who celebrate well have higher satisfaction.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: All these benefits are real. Celebration provides multiple forms of relationship nourishment.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared understanding of celebration's value creates motivation to acknowledge each other's wins more often.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How does celebrating together benefit your relationship? What would more celebration look like?
